Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: The Development of Higher Voltage, Longer Life and Lower Cost Activated Carbon Materials for Supercapacitors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in significantly increasing the ways supercapacitors and lithium ion batteries are used today. Supercapacitors offer very high power capabilities and high energy efficiency and have been used in many renewable energy applications such as hybrid buses and wind turbines. Currently, their use is limited due to high cost and low energy density relative to Li-ion batteries. Coulometrics has developed a proprietary process that can modify low cost activated carbon materials into supercapacitor grade carbons with 25% higher energy density and twice the current lifespan of existing materials. These critical developments will lower the overall system cost and improve cell life allowing for more widespread use of supercapacitors in renewable energy applications. Coulometrics has also shown that a very similar process can be used to convert natural graphite to lithium ion grade anode materials with higher energy density and significantly lower cost. This process will also enable a Northern American company to become the first producer of graphite for lithium ion batteries on the continent which can significantly reduce lithium ion battery cost for applications such as electric vehicles. Both projects will have additional environmental benefits including reduced greenhouse gas emissions, less burning of fossil fuels, and help protect the environment.



The project seeks to break through a significant barrier that has kept ultracapacitor voltage and energy density stagnant for over a decade and significantly reduce costs of lithium ion battery carbon materials. Supercapacitor companies all produce products with different carbons, electrolytes, cell construction, etc. and yet are all confined to the same performance specifications. We believe that this is related to oxidation/reduction reactions that occur on the carbon surface; a fairly intuitive hypothesis; however attempts at solutions have been futile. The surface treatment we developed in Phase I has resulted in a reduction of these oxidation/reduction currents by more than 50%. This technology will lead to the largest performance gains in the ultracapacitor industry in over 10 years. Additionally, one of the most challenging factors limiting market growth for ultracapacitors is their high cost, of which activated carbon accounts for 27%. Coulometrics' treatment applied to inexpensive water filtration carbon, also developed in Phase I, has shown very similar performance enhancements, and will cost up to 95% less than commercial activated carbon materials. The surface modification process for graphitic carbons will enable the low cost and high quality production of carbon anode materials for lithium ion batteries based on natural graphite. This breakthrough can significantly reduce lithium ion battery cost which is a key element for more wide spread adoption of electric vehicles which will help reduce our nation's dependence on the need to import foreign oil.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project has successfully developed a new process for coating EDLC (supercapacitor) activated carbon and natural graphite for lithium ion battery (LIB) applications.  The coating for EDLC activated carbon allows for the development of longer life supercapacitors with superior temperature and life stability.  For LIB graphite, the coating process offers an alternative to conventional pitch-based coating and results in a much more uniform and lower cost production process that is more suitable for automotive applications.  A significant emerging benefit of the coating technology is the potential to establish a North American supply chain for LIB-grade natural graphite from flake graphite that can be mined in Canada or the United States.  Currently, China produces 95% of the LIB-grade natural graphite and there are no known producers in the United States.

Conventional processes for the production on LIB-grade natural graphite from mined graphite flake concentrate include:

  1. Spheronization of the graphite flake to produce 10-30um graphite spheroidal particles.
  2. Acid purification using a combination of hydrofluoric and sulfuric acid which may also include hydrochloric acid.
  3. Coating of the purified graphite spheroids using petroleum or coal-tar pitch.
  4. Calcination of the coating to make it suitable for LIB applications.

This process is generally done in China due to the use of hydrofluoric acid.  There have been a number of environmental concerns that have been reported by the Washington Post.  The contents of which can be found at the following URL: https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/business/batteries/graphite-mining-pollution-in-china/.

In contrast, Coulometrics has been working to develop a new coating technology that would eliminate the pitch-coating process and subsequent need for calcination of the coating.  This new process is based on a novel CVD-coating that is highly cost effective and results increased capacity and first cycle efficiency of the LIB graphite material.  Coulometrics has also been working with several leading thermal processing companies in the United States to develop an alternative process with the following advantages:

  1. Reduced product cost that is critical to enable wider-spread adoption of electric vehicles.
  2. An environmentally friendly process with virtually no greenhouse gas emissions compared to conventional technology.
  3. Increased product consistency, lower impurities, higher capacity, and generally improved suitability for the emerging US LIB production for automotive applications.

During this program, Coulometrics fully evaluated the graphite materials produced using Coulometrics' production slurry mixing and slot-die coating systems.  Coulometrics also installed a dry room, 18650 assembly equipment, and state-of-the-art high precision coulometry testing systems for accelerated life testing.  Performance of the produced graphite materials in LIBs was very similar to cells that were taken from Tesla Model S battery packs, which is surprising considering the Coulometrics cells did not employ advanced cathode materials, separator, or electrolytes.  Samples of the graphite materials have been supplied to three US cell assembly companies and initial results indicate that the performance is the same or better than current graphite materials.  Coulometrics and our thermal processing partner are currently working to begin selling an initial grade of graphite in 2017.

The broader impacts of this project are numerous.  First, Coulometrics has been able to develop state-of-the-art graphite materials for LIB applications and is working to commercialize this material in the United States.  Considerable knowledge and expertise has been developed and will hopefully seed a future US-based supply chain for LIB grade graphite.  The current market for graphite is approximately 75,000 tonnes per year and expected to grow to over 150,000 tonnes per year in 2020 due to demand in the automotive sector for EVs.  This represents a $1.5B global market that we expect in the future will feature at least 50% US market share.  The development of this process also helps provide a market for US and Canadian junior graphite companies.  There are considerable resources of graphite in North America with supporting junior graphite mining organizations.  We are currently working with a number of these companies however these projects cannot raise the necessary funds to build  mine without a suitable value-added products to produce.  LIB-grade graphite could be the solution that would allow some of these projects to be financed.  Finally, Coulometrics has also determined, during the course of this program, that the graphite anode electrode in a LIB has a considerable impact on the life of LIBs.  Coulometrics continues to develop better graphite materials and is working closely with 2 leading cell manufacturers as a result of this program to develop longer life LIBs that could be critical in the future to develop more cost effective EVs.

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2016
Modified by: Edward R Buiel
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project has successfully developed a new process for coating EDLC (supercapacitor) activated carbon and natural graphite for lithium ion battery (LIB) applications. The coating for EDLC activated carbon allows for the development of longer life supercapacitors with superior temperature and life stability. For LIB graphite, the coating process offers an alternative to conventional pitch-based coating and results in a much more uniform and lower cost production process that is more suitable for automotive applications. A significant emerging benefit of the coating technology is the potential to establish a North American supply chain for LIB-grade natural graphite from flake graphite that can be mined in Canada or the United States. Currently, China produces 95% of the LIB-grade natural graphite and there are no known producers in the United States. Conventional processes for the production on LIB-grade natural graphite from mined graphite flake concentrate include: Spheronization of the graphite flake to produce 10-30um graphite spheroidal particles. Acid purification using a combination of hydrofluoric and sulfuric acid which may also include hydrochloric acid. Coating of the purified graphite spheroids using petroleum or coal-tar pitch. Calcination of the coating to make it suitable for LIB applications. This process is generally done in China due to the use of hydrofluoric acid. There have been a number of environmental concerns that have been reported by the Washington Post. The contents of which can be found at the following URL: https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/business/batteries/graphite-mining-pollution-in-china/. In contrast, Coulometrics has been working to develop a new coating technology that would eliminate the pitch-coating process and subsequent need for calcination of the coating. This new process is based on a novel CVD-coating that is highly cost effective and results increased capacity and first cycle efficiency of the LIB graphite material. Coulometrics has also been working with several leading thermal processing companies in the United States to develop an alternative process with the following advantages: Reduced product cost that is critical to enable wider-spread adoption of electric vehicles. An environmentally friendly process with virtually no greenhouse gas emissions compared to conventional technology. Increased product consistency, lower impurities, higher capacity, and generally improved suitability for the emerging US LIB production for automotive applications. During this program, Coulometrics fully evaluated the graphite materials produced using Coulometrics' production slurry mixing and slot-die coating systems. Coulometrics also installed a dry room, 18650 assembly equipment, and state-of-the-art high precision coulometry testing systems for accelerated life testing. Performance of the produced graphite materials in LIBs was very similar to cells that were taken from Tesla Model S battery packs, which is surprising considering the Coulometrics cells did not employ advanced cathode materials, separator, or electrolytes. Samples of the graphite materials have been supplied to three US cell assembly companies and initial results indicate that the performance is the same or better than current graphite materials. Coulometrics and our thermal processing partner are currently working to begin selling an initial grade of graphite in 2017. The broader impacts of this project are numerous. First, Coulometrics has been able to develop state-of-the-art graphite materials for LIB applications and is working to commercialize this material in the United States. Considerable knowledge and expertise has been developed and will hopefully seed a future US-based supply chain for LIB grade graphite. The current market for graphite is approximately 75,000 tonnes per year and expected to grow to over 150,000 tonnes per year in 2020 due to demand in the automotive sector for EVs. This represents a $1.5B global market that we expect in the future will feature at least 50% US market share. The development of this process also helps provide a market for US and Canadian junior graphite companies. There are considerable resources of graphite in North America with supporting junior graphite mining organizations. We are currently working with a number of these companies however these projects cannot raise the necessary funds to build mine without a suitable value-added products to produce. LIB-grade graphite could be the solution that would allow some of these projects to be financed. Finally, Coulometrics has also determined, during the course of this program, that the graphite anode electrode in a LIB has a considerable impact on the life of LIBs. Coulometrics continues to develop better graphite materials and is working closely with 2 leading cell manufacturers as a result of this program to develop longer life LIBs that could be critical in the future to develop more cost effective EVs.
